title: Ixodes kaiseri
text:
Ixodes kaiseri is an <a href="Old%20World">Old World</a> species of <a href="Ixodidae">ixodid</a> <a href="tick">tick</a> that <a href="Parasite">parasitizes</a> <a href="badger">badger</a>s, <a href="fox">fox</a>es, <a href="steppe%20polecat">steppe polecat</a>s, <a href="raccoon%20dog">raccoon dog</a>s, and common <a href="hedgehog">hedgehog</a>s in <a href="forest">forest</a> habitats and along heavily overgrown riverbanks and depressions in <a href="steppe">steppe</a> habitats; they have also been collected from domestic <a href="dog">dog</a>s visiting these habitats. The <a href="Specific%20epithet%20%28zoology%29">specific epithet</a> honors the scientific contributions of Dr. <a href="Makram%20N.%20Kaiser">Makram N. Kaiser</a>.
"Ixodes kaiseri" occurs in <a href="Republic%20of%20Moldavia">Moldavia</a>, southern <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> and <a href="Crimea">Crimea</a>, <a href="Romania">Romania</a>, <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> and <a href="Israel">Israel</a>, with single finds recorded from the northern <a href="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, <a href="Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> and <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a>. Its <a href="Range%20%28biology%29">range</a> overlaps that of "<a href="Ixodes%20crenulatus">Ixodes crenulatus</a>", with corresponding developmental stages found together on the same hosts.
All <a href="Hemimetabolism">developmental stages</a> of "I. kaiseri" are found on its host animals from March through October, with hosts highly infested in March and April after hibernation and all tick developmental stages, most in a fed condition, present. Males are rarely found on hosts, suggesting that in this species, as in other burrow-inhabiting ixodids, the adult males do not feed, and <a href="Mating">copulation</a> occurs in the burrows.
